awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation: Analyzing inequities in undergraduate workforce opportunities between biomedical and other engineering disciplines
awd_abstract_narration:
Biomedical Engineering majors have been shown to exhibit higher rates of transfer to different engineering majors, lower rates of internship and career employment offers, and lower average starting salary compared to other engineering majors. These inequities in undergraduate workforce opportunities are having adverse effects on the professional formation of Biomedical Engineers. This study seeks to initiate a characterization of the challenges in the university-to-industry pipeline through investigating workforce opportunity between biomedical engineers and three other engineering majors at a large Midwestern University. Undergraduate biomedical engineering programs commonly have a high percentage of female students, therefore identifying inequities, improving retention, and maintaining appropriate pathways into the workforce is required. This research provides context upon which broadening participation in biomedical engineering can be furthered, as well as establishes foundations upon which further work can inform interventions designed to mitigate negative impacts.

Through a theoretical lens of Social Cognitive Career Theory a multivariate regression analysis is implemented on existing data to compare different factors of undergraduate workforce opportunity and student profiles.  Through Social Cognitive Career Theory, student self-efficacy, outcome expectations, and contextual supports and barriers that influence students' interests in their chosen engineering majors and post-graduation plans are investigated. A validated, transferable survey tool is established by adapting existing Social Cognitive Career Theory measures and adapting the model of career choice to the problem domain of undergraduate engineering workforce opportunity. Self-efficacy, outcome expectation, and supports and barriers are the Social Cognitive Career Theory constructs that will comprise the independent variables within the developed assessment tool. Existing instruments will be adapted and validated for each of these constructs to provide insight into students' interests (dependent variable) in engineering major and post-graduation plans.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
This work has found a way to understand what factors contribute to an engineering undergraduate student's support, barriers and factors that contribute to a particular career outcome (e.g. industry, graduate school or other alternatives). The analytical methods and instruments created in this work can be used by engineering departments or career services to uncover previously unknown factors that positively or negatively affect students' career paths decisions. This work has yielded 3 conference proceeding papers and 2 journal publications (currently in review and preparation). It has proposed a quantitative and qualitative approach to better understand academic and performance factors that can potentially influence a student's decisions to pursue a specific career outcome (e.g., industry or graduate school). This research led to the creation of an instrument to evaluate support and barriers present in the engineering undergraduate students' pursuit of said outcomes. This work has also enhanced the knowledge on engineering education qualitative and quantitative methodologies for both PI and Co-PIs.  
   
Intellectual Merit:  

  • The combination of student data from academic records and career service interactions (e.g. attendance to job fair, recruitment, career attainment) to uncover patterns between engineering majors.  

  • The codification of individual student experiences from different majors to understand what their experiences and thoughts are towards their career goals.  

  • The creation of a new instrument (undergraduate engineering workforce opportunity assessment) based on the Social Cognitive Career Theory framework to explain what factors contribute to student's decisions around their decided career outcome.  

Broader Impacts:  

  • The utilized statistical and analytical methods could be used by departments and career services around the nation to better inform decisions on how to prepare students, look for companies or create interventions for students who are unsure about career outcomes.  


Last Modified: 01/10/2023
Modified by: David A A Delaine

This research led to the creation of an instrument to evaluate support and barriers present in the engineering undergraduate students' pursuit of said outcomes. The combination of student data from academic records and career service interactions (e.g. attendance to job fair, recruitment, career attainment) to uncover patterns between engineering majors.
